title: Money Stress
description: Assess how money affects your emotional wellbeing together

questions.text: Money worries don't negatively affect my mood in our relationship.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial stress often spills into relationship mood—creating irritability, withdrawal, or conflict. Awareness of this connection is the first step to managing it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner's money stress affects the relationship more, explore how to create boundaries between financial worry and relationship quality.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared experience—whether stress-free or stressed—means you can address it together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does financial stress show up in how you relate to your partner?

questions.text: I sense healthy coping when money stress comes up between us.

therapeutic.rationale: How your partner handles financial stress—whether through avoidance, anxiety, blame, or problem-solving—affects your relationship. Healthy coping protects the partnership.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner sees unhealthy coping, discuss specific behaviors and their impact. Often people don't realize how their stress response affects others.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared perception of healthy coping creates confidence in facing financial challenges.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner cope with money stress? How does it affect you?

questions.text: I can talk to my partner when I'm feeling financially stressed.

therapeutic.rationale: Being able to share financial stress with your partner provides emotional support and prevents isolation. Hiding stress often makes it worse.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't share stress easily, explore what makes it difficult. Fear of judgment? Not wanting to worry the other? These barriers can be addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to share financial stress creates emotional partnership around money.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes it easy or hard to share money worries with your partner?

questions.text: I feel supported when I'm anxious about money.

therapeutic.rationale: Supportive responses to financial anxiety strengthen your bond. Dismissive or critical responses leave you feeling alone with your worries.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel supported, discuss what support looks like. Sometimes partners try to help by minimizing worries, which doesn't feel supportive.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of support during financial stress creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What kind of support do you need when you're worried about money?

questions.text: I believe we can keep money stress from damaging our connection.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence that you can protect your relationship from financial stress reflects emotional maturity and commitment. This belief helps you stay connected during difficult times.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is less confident, explore what would help. Specific agreements about how to handle stress? More communication?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in protecting your connection from money stress is a relationship strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would help you keep financial stress from affecting your relationship?
